RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Engenheiro Agronomo (1999) pelo Instituto Agronфmico e Veterinбrio Hassan II (Marrocos), mestre (2008) em the Safe Production in Horticulture pela University of Copenhagen (Dinamarca) e pela Universitа degli Studi di Catania (Italia). Doutorado (2012) em Entomological Sciences and Agro-systems Protection pela Universitа degli Studi di Catania (Italia). De 2013 a 2019 foi Pуs-Doutor no programa de Pуs-Graduaзгo em Entomologia da UFV (Conceito 7 da CAPES), inicialmente atravйs do programa Ciкncia sem Fronteiras na modalidade Bolsa Jovens Talentos (2013-2016) e depois como bolsista PNPD. Desde 2019 й professor no Departamento de Entomologia da Universidade Federal de Lavras ( UFLA) onde orienta estudantes de mestrado e doutorado nos programas de Pуs-Graduaзгo em Entomologia (Conceito 5 da CAPES). Participa do programa de Pуs-Graduaзгo em Biotecnologia da Universidade Federal de Tocantins UFT-Campus de Gurupi. Desenvolve estudos nas бreas de agronomia (e.g., entomologia e fitossanidade), ecotoxicologia e biologia molecular, com кnfase nos seguintes temas: toxicologia de inseticidas e resistкncia de insetos a inseticidas, aspectos moleculares da aзгo de inseticidas em receptores e canais iфnicos, fisiologia e comportamento de insetos (principalmente locomoзгo e percepзгo de odores de invertebrados) e efeitos subletais de inseticidas e уleos essenciais. Й membro do comitк editorial de revista Entomologia Generalis e CABI Agriculture and Bioscience e revisor por vбrios jornais e revistas nacionais e internacionais.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Agricultural Engineer (1999) from the Hassan II Agricultural and Veterinary Institute (Morocco), Master (2008) in the Safe Production in Horticulture from the University of Copenhagen (Denmark) and the Universitа degli Studi di Catania (Italy). PhD (2012) in Entomological Sciences and Agro-systems Protection from the Universitа degli Studi di Catania (Italy). From 2013 to 2019 he was a postdoctoral fellow in the Postgraduate Program in Entomology at UFV (CAPES Concept 7), initially through the Science Without Borders program in the Bolsa Jovem Talentos modality (2013-2016) and later as a PNPD scholarship holder. Since 2019 he has been a professor at the Department of Entomology at the Federal University of Lavras (UFLA) where he advises master and doctoral students in the Postgraduate Programs in Entomology (CAPES Concept 5). Participates in the Graduate Program in Biotechnology of the Federal University of Tocantins UFT-Campus de Gurupi. Develops studies in the areas of agronomy (eg, entomology ), ecotoxicology and molecular biology, with emphasis on the following topics: insecticide toxicology and insect resistance to insecticides, molecular aspects of insecticide action on ion receptors and channels, Arthropods' physiology and behavior. (mainly locomotion and odors perception) and sublethal effects of insecticides and plant base compounds. He is a member of the editorial board of Entomologia Generalis and a reviewer for several national and international journals.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Bases moleculares da aзгo de inseticidas neurotуxicos e bioprospecзгo de novas ferramentas para o controle do percevejo-marrom-da-soja, Euschistus heros
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: As aplicaзхes de inseticidas neurotуxicos neonicotinoides e piretroides tкm sido consideradas as ferramentas mais eficazes para o controle do complexo de percevejos (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae) que atacam a cultura da soja. Entretanto, estudos recentes tкm apontado falhas no controle destas pragas, principalmente em relaзгo ao percevejo-marrom-da-soja, Euschistus heros, principal alvo das aplicaзхes de neonicotinoides e piretroides. Ainda que outros fatores possam estar envolvidos neste cenбrio, a ocorrкncia de populaзхes de E. heros resistentes aos inseticidas consiste na principal hipуtese por trбs das recorrentes falhas de controle observadas. Portanto, a presente proposta serб conduzida com o objetivo de investigar as bases moleculares da aзгo e da resistкncia a inseticidas neonicotinoides e piretroides em populaзхes de E. heros e, tambйm, bioprospectar novas ferramentas para o controle desta praga. Dentro deste contexto, populaзхes de E. heros coletadas em Minas Gerais e em outras regiхes brasileiras produtoras de soja serгo inicialmente submetidas a bioensaios para seleзгo de indivнduos resistentes. Uma vez detectada o fenфmeno da resistкncia, estudos moleculares-fisiolуgicos (e.g., expressгo e quantificaзгo da atividade de genes responsбveis pela expressгo de enzimas destoxificativas ou dos canais iфnicos alvos principais da aзгo das molйculas inseticidas) serгo conduzidos para identificaзгo de potenciais modificaзхes nos indivнduos resistentes. Adicionalmente, bioensaios discriminatуrios de susceptibilidade serгo utilizados para averiguar o potencial de novos inseticidas (sejam eles de origem sintйtica ou natural) para o controle de E. heros. Portanto, estes resultados indicarгo nгo somente a situaзгo atual, mas tambйm proporcionarгo as bases para a adoзгo de medidas preventivas que resultarгo, em ъltima anбlise, na possibilidade de efetuarmos um manejo mais eficiente desta praga

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Physiological bases of agricultural and environmental pollutants actions on Neotropical aquatic insects
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Contamination of aquatic ecosystems by agricultural and industrial pollutants is a serious challenge for the environments? sustainability. The overuse of pesticides and chemical fertilizers in agriculture as well as industrial wastes and spillages from normal mining activities or following environmental disasters are considered the major pollution sources. Thus, understanding the toxicities and sublethal effects of pesticides, heavy metals and other pollutants to non-target functional groups of aquatic insects is critical for predicting effects on ecosystem functions. In the Brazilian context, only few studies on the environmental bioindicator potential of some insect groups (e.g., Ephemeropterans, Plecoptera and Odonata) are available. More recently, however, studies pointed that the application of insecticides aiming to control vector insects like mosquitoes can lead to insecticide exposures of some aquatic insect predators, which had resulted in physiological and behavioral (especially the predatory abilities) alterations . Therefore, this work will be conducted with the objective of evaluating the susceptibility of giant water bug Belostoma anurum (Hemiptera: Belostomatidae) to major water pollutants including pesticides from various classes (e.g., pyrethroids, organophosphates, neonicotinoids, IGR, herbicides) as well as heavy metals (cadmium, [Cd] and lead [Pb]). The focus will be on the physiological, behavioral and molecular alterations triggered by lethal and sublethal exposure not only in the predator (B. anurum) alone but also in interaction with its preys (larvae of the mosquitoes Aedes spp). Besides the mortality and survival bioassays, possible cellular alterations present in the nervous and digestive systems both of the predator and its preys, as well as modifications in the predatory capacity will be evaluated following exposure to the pollutants. Moreover, the oxidative stress will be analyzed at biochemical and molecular levels in an attempt to observe the response of the antioxidant machinery of B. anurum under xenobiotics pollution conditions.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Biochemical Mechanisms Associated With Oxidiazine Resistance in Brazilian Populations of Sitophilus sp. (Coleoptera: Curculionidae).
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The intense use of insecticides during the past decades led to serious pest control failures. In Brazil, resistance to several insecticides, including pyrethroids, have been related to the successive record of losses registered in storage units, mainly due to infestation of the weevil species Sitophilus zeamais and Sitophilus oryzae. Recent studies showed the involvement of a single mutation in sodium channels in the reduction of pyrethroid sensitivity in S. zeamais. However, this single mutation could not explain alone the high levels of resistance observed in these insect species, making the understanding of the molecular basis of resistance a remaining task to be executed. With insecticide resistance threatening the future of pyrethroids, there is an urgent need to develop alternative insecticides for insect pest control in storage units. The oxadiazine indoxacarb has showed efficient control levels of other coleopterans as the boll weevil Anthonomus grandis and the potato bettle Lepinotarsa decemlineata. Although there is no permission yet for utilizing oxidiazine in the control of stored grain insect pests in Brazil, our first investigations on the susceptibility of Brazilian population of S. zeamais to indoxacarb revealed the existence of resistance cases. These studies showed that this resistance is not linked to the kdr mutation already described or to any other previously reported mutation in domain 2 of sodium channels. This indicates that metabolic (enzymatic) mechanisms might be behind the found resistance cases. Therefore, this work proposes to perform molecular and enzymatic investigations, identifying potential upregulated genes in these insects that might reduce indoxacarb sensitivity.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Molecular characterization of the sodium channel para-orthologus gene and identification of mutations putatively associated with pyrethroid resistance in Brazilian populations of Sitophilus spp. (Coleoptera: Curculionidae)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Sodium channels are transmembrane proteins responsible for the initiation and propagation of action potentials in the nervous system and other excitable cells. These channels constitute the major target site for actions of insecticides such as DDT and pyrethroids, compounds used worldwide in the control of virtually all agriculturally and medically important insect pests. However, the intense use of these molecules led to the selection of individuals resistant to these compounds, resulting in serious pest control failures. A major mechanism of DDT and pyrethroid resistance, known as knockdown resistance (kdr), is caused by point mutations in sodium channels. In Brazil, resistance to these insecticides have been related to the successive record of losses registered in stored product units, mainly due to infestation of the weevil species Sitophilus zeamais and Sitophilus oryzae. Particularly in S. zeamais, recent information indicates to existence of kdr mutations as a major resistance mechanism to pyrethroids. However, the understanding of the molecular basis of pyrethroid resistance in S. zeamais remains a task to be executed. Therefore, this work proposes to perform the molecular full-length characterization of the para-orthologous gene (gene responsible for the sodium channels expression) in both S. zeamais and S. oryzae, identifying potential mutations in these channels that might reduce pyrethroid sensitivity

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Asian Pacific Journal of Tropical Medicine

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Department of Agri-food and Environmental Systems Management

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Studies on insecticide resistance in Tuta absoluta (meyrick), with special emphasis on characterisation of two target site mechanisms
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Tuta absoluta Meyrick (Lepidoptera: Gelechiidae) is a primary pest of tomato plants and is native to South America. Since the first documented European case in 2006, it has spread throughout the Mediterranean basin and North Africa. Chemical insecticides have been the main control tools used against T. absoluta, but decreasing efficacy has been attributed to the development of insecticide resistance. One important mechanism of resistance to pyrethroids, termed knockdown resistance (kdr), has been shown to arise through alterations (point mutations) in the para-type sodium channel protein leading to reduced sensitivity of the insect nervous system to the pyrethroids. Mutations in the Ace gene have also been reported to cause insensitivity to organophosphates. 
During this study, leaf-dip bioassays will be used to quantify responses of field strains of T. absoluta to insecticides belonging to different chemical classes. A combination of PCR-based molecular methods and biochemical assays will be used to investigate possible existence of any mutations in two insecticides targets in several laboratory strains. Diagnostic tools that allow detection in individual larvae and adults will be developed and used to screen field samples of diverse geographical origin and assess their distribution in global T. absoluta populations.
